post: 📜  #OTD in 1796, George Washingtons Farewell Address was published in The American Daily Advertiser, offering guidance on unity, partisanship, and foreign policy. How can these ideas shape civic leadership today? Lesson on Washingtons integrity:  https://bit.ly/4pom9YV  #TDiH  #CivicEducation  #CivicLeadership  #AmericanHistory

Friendly challenge: Which state will put the most Pocket Constitutions into students hands this month? Back your state and tag a friend to join you. Give:  https://bit.ly/40EsBAg  #CivicsChampion  #StatePride  #CivicEducation  #SupportTeachers

How did John Dickinson, the Penman of the Revolution,  shape the American founding? Historian Jane Calvert joins BRI Scholar Talks to unpack his ideas on prudence, liberty, and constitutional design. Watch and share your takeaway:  https://bit.ly/4n5sjvj  #CivicEducation  #AmericanFounding  #JohnDickinson  #Constitution  #ScholarTalks

How do state and federal powers shape our constitutional rights? In this interview, Kirk Higgins and Anastasia Boden discuss federalism, liberty, and the vital role of the judiciary branch. Watch now:  https://bit.ly/4n9iBIt  #CivicEducation  #Federalism  #Constitution

Your next hotel booking could fund a classroom ✈️ With TravelingToGive, part of every trip you take supports the Bill of Rights Institutes mission to provide free civic education. Where will your travels take you? 🧳 Start here:  https://bit.ly/43XWUUk  #TravelingToGive  #CivicEducation  #SupportTeachers  #TravelForGood

📜  #OTD in 1787, delegates at the Constitutional Convention approved the U. S. Constitution, sending it to the states for ratification. What can this moment teach students about compromise in self-government? Use this lesson to spark discussion:  https://bit.ly/4mme980  #TDiH  #CivicEducation  #ConstitutionDay  #SelfGovernment

In 1787, delegates in Philadelphia debated fiercely over liberty, representation, and executive power. Their compromises created the U. S. Constitution, and a model of self-government still debated today. Watch our new A250 mini-documentary:  https://bit.ly/4grIDDW  #ConstitutionDay  #America250  #CivicEducation  #AmericanHistory

Were thrilled to announce Veronica Pitts of Selma High School as BRIs National Civics Teacher of the Year! 🎉 Her dedication empowers students to understand and embrace their civic role in our democracy. Proud thanks to FileWave for sponsoring this award. 🔗 Check out what makes Veronica this years winner:  https://bit.ly/4gog4Y8  #CivicEducation  #CivicTeachers  #Civics

Looking for engaging classroom resources for Constitution Day? 🎉 The Civic Star Challenge offers free lessons + activities to bring the Constitution to life. Check it out:  https://bit.ly/3V1CQuX  #ConstitutionDay  #CivicStarChallenge  #CivicEducation  #TeachingResources

📜 Constitution Day Live is almost here! On Sept. 17, the Bill of Rights Institute will celebrate the signing of the Constitution with new videos, resources, and classroom tools to help teachers bring civics to life. This years theme, Democracy in Your Backyard,  highlights how constitutional principles shape both historic struggles and everyday choices. Educators and students can look forward to: ✅ Civics on the Street with Catholic Universitys Prof. Matthew Green answering student questions. ✅ A new Primary Source Essentials video on the constitutional amendment process. ✅ Democracy in Action, exploring how the Constitution has guided Americans through pivotal moments in history. ✅ A spotlight on William Mar, the grand prize winner of BRIs MyImpact Challenge. And on Constitution Day itself, well premiere 3 more videos, including a civic leadership story, a mini-documentary on the Constitutional Convention, and a federalism discussion with Anastasia Boden of the Pacific Legal Foundation. ➡️ Read more and access resources:  https://bit.ly/3Ipvr5Y  #ConstitutionDay  #CivicEducation  #TeachingResources  #CivicEngagement
